description: From Middle English behinde, behinden, from Old English behindan (“on the back side of, behind”), equivalent to be- +‎ hind. Compare Old Saxon bihindan (“behind”, adverb), Middle High German behinter (“behind; back”).

adjectives.description: behind (comparative more behind or (rare or nonstandard) behinder, superlative most behind or (rare or nonstandard) behindest)

entries.meaning: Not advanced to the required or expected degree; overdue or in arrears.
examples: I'm very behind in my schedule.
My employer is two paychecks behind on paying my salary.

entries.meaning: (of a watch or clock) Slow.
examples: My watch is behind by four minutes.

adverbs.description: behind (comparative more behind or (rare or nonstandard) behinder, superlative most behind or (rare or nonstandard) behindest)

entries.meaning: At or in the rear or back part of something.
examples: The water flows out through the pipe, and the sediment collects behind.

entries.meaning: In a rearward direction.
examples: We ran and ran, without once looking behind.

entries.meaning: So as to come after someone or something in position, distance, advancement, ranking, time, etc.
examples: The slower runners were left a long way behind.
In the cricket match, England finished a long way behind.
The worst thing about autumn is that winter follows behind.

entries.meaning: So as to be still in place after someone or something has departed or ceased to exist.
examples: I couldn't be bothered to carry the ironing board, so I left it behind.
He stayed behind after the war.
He left behind a legacy of death and sorrow.
The island was inundated by the sea, leaving not a trace behind.

entries.meaning: Backward in time or order of succession; past.
Behind the scenes in a theatre; backstage.
(archaic) Not yet brought forward, produced, or exhibited to view; out of sight; remaining.
The rear, back-end.
examples: This part fits under the behind of the vehicle.
She sneaked up on me from behind.

entries.meaning: (informal) The buttocks, bottom, butt.
examples: I was stung on the behind by a wasp.

entries.meaning: (Australian rules football) A one-point score.
(baseball, slang, 1800s) The catcher.
In the Eton College field game, any of a group of players consisting of two "shorts" (who try to kick the ball over the bully) and a "long" (who defends the goal).

definitionGroups.group: At or to the back or far side of.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Concealed by (something serving as a facade or disguise).
examples: Behind the smile was a cruel intention.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) In the past, from the viewpoint of.
examples: All my problems are behind me.

definitionGroups.group: Less forward or advanced than; after.

entries.meaning: After in physical progress or distance.
examples: Smith finished the race a lap behind the others.

entries.meaning: After in developmental progress, score, grade, etc.; inferior to.
examples: I'm ranked sixth in the French class, behind five other pupils.
In the cricket match, England are 120 runs behind India.

entries.meaning: After in time.
examples: London is nine hours behind Tokyo.

entries.meaning: Responsible for, being the creator or controller of.
examples: Who is behind these terrorist attacks?
Mr Jones was the man behind the redevelopment plan.

entries.meaning: Underlying, being the reason for or explanation of.
examples: What is behind this unexpected decision?

entries.meaning: In support of.
examples: The republicans are fully behind their candidate.

entries.meaning: (nonstandard, US, slang) As a result or consequence of.
